ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Esty is a pro.
This course has lots to offer from politics, policy to international negotiations on climate change andenergy. This was one of the best courses i have taken at Yale
Decent course. Esty is a great speaker. I would have liked a deeper dive on fewer subjects. Thought thecourse was "just scratching the surface" a bit too much.
Best course I've taken at Yale. Esty is a treasure.
excellent course, hope other students with similar interests will benefit from it

Some of the texts we read, such as Coal, didn't play strongly into discussion, but I still felt obligated to read them.Very well organized class, including the field trip, which ran like butter, and had some very interesting stops. Prof. Esty was a pleasure to learn from, and, unlike many professors who say they value group discussion, actually let the class do most of the talking.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: How engaging our discussions were; Dan's "lecture" style; breadth and depth of topics covered

I didn't have an extensive background in energy policy, so this class was a mega energy download for me. Esty has a wealth of experience and knowledge that he brings to the table and he stimulated some lively discussion. He was also excited to put ideas from the course into practice. This course manifested both an earth day teach out and a meeting with the president (for some students) about steps Yale can take towards energy efficiency/reducing emissions.
The lectures.
Daily class discussions were enriching
Esty is a great speaker. Good class discussions.
Professor was an incredible communicator and created a really interesting dialogue with the class on a daily basis. The law school needs more more environmental/energy classes like this .

The best aspect of the course was the discussion of trade-offs in environmental problems as a central theme. We kept coming back to this problem of trade-offs and this enabled us to analyze such a complex problem like climate change more clearly and allowed us to frame the problem differently.

I loved the discussions facilitated by the class. It was a large class, but the size actually was an advantage because we were able to incorporate many different opinions into our discussions. I felt challenged by this course to think creatively and I think I got a lot out of it.
All

Being in a stimulating environment of students from three different graduate schools plus Yale College. Hearing firsthand accounts from Prof. Esty about his time at the Copenhagen COP and his experience working in state government.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Sometimes we got lost in the weeds or stuck on a topic, such that the course fell behind the syllabus. I like that Esty stimulated good discussion, but I think he could have reigned us and himself in more, at times. We spent a few too many days repeating the debate between cap and trade and the carbon tax. We also spent too much time on geoengineering - that could easily have been limited to half a class.
More technical details.
The course set up was perfect

Dive deeper on specific subjects. Esty's main value is that he has participated in backroom discussions on these subjects. Share as much of that information with the class as possible. Cover less subjects.
A bit more focus on the law and legal issues.

I think there should be a stronger emphasis on the solutions and also more discussion of legal tools and legislations applicable to the topic of climate change. I think there can also be more discussion of the comparative institutional analysis.

The class had a difficult time moving away from policy and politics discussions into alternate ways of addressing climate problems (private sector for example), but it was still very informative and didn't repeat itself too much.
Excellent so far.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes very effective
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This started as a sponging knowledge course for me, but may end up being a direction I pursue more seriously.
Good policy course to work in science/policy world
Since i have to provide advice to my government on environmental issues including climate change and energy, this course worked so well for me
This my primary interest , so the course fits in my overall program
Undergraduate hoping to be part of the new Energy Studies Certifiate program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in climate change solutions
Energy and climate change effect so many other arenas, I think it's valuable to have some knowledge of energy policy if you are planning on working domestically.
Interest
Learn more about climate change and energy policy
Wanted to take course with Esty. Lack of other energy courses at FES.

Having enjoyed Professor Esty's lecture style from the first class, I wanted to take the class to become more articulate when talking about climate change, which is the core environmental issue of our time. I also wanted to be able to partake in discussions that include students from many different graduate schools, which indeed produced many great discussions throughout the semester.
Because I needed to better understand the nexus energy -climate, through a variety of angles ( policy, law, economic, social, etc)

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely. One of the top classes during my time at Yale.
Yes.
Above and beyond.
Absolutely!
Kind of.
Absolutely, I feel very well prepared to take on any climate and energy challenge that may come my way.
Yes it met my expectations

Yes, we approached the climate-energy issue very thoroughly, and from many angles. sometimes it felt like we were jointly banging our heads on the wall, trying to solve a difficult, real-world problem. This was partly why Prof. Esty had the idea of putting on the "Teach Out for Climate Change" Earth Day event, which was a perfect compliment to the course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Students in this class comes from diverse background and i learned so much from their rich diverse perspectives
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Engage during class!
You don't have to do all of the readings, but the law students will, so you should have an overarching sense of them.

Overall a great course. If you have a background in Energy systems , engineering, or business some of the material will be a review. However, Professor Esty's insights into the policy process and his personal experience are invaluable. I would recommend this course without hesitation.
This is a must class for everyone interested in climate change and energy policy and politics.
It's a great course if you are not very familiar with climate/energy issues. If you are familiar, it doesn't offer as much value.
Take the course.
Do it.

This was my favorite course at Yale so far, largely because of Professor Esty. He made it exciting and very useful while intellectually challenging. I would love to take it again if I could. Take this class ifyou are at all interested in climate and clean energy from a policy perspective.
If offered, please take this class
There is lots of reading, but Prof. Esty expects that you will "read at various speeds."
